Award.AwardTitle: IEEE Health Innovation and Point-of-Care Technologies 2014 Conference Student Scholarships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports student involvement in the 2014 IEEE Conference on Healthcare Innovations and Point-of-Care Technologies to be held in Seattle, WA, on October 8-10, 2014. This conference is focused on potential innovative technology solutions to challenges associated with care delivery. It includes panel discussions, scientific and clinical presentations, and breakout sessions. The conference will also offer students the opportunity to participate in an IDEO design innovation workshop in which students will work with clinicians and engineers to develop and conceptualize innovative ideas for healthcare applications. The goal of this project is to involve students in all facets of the conference, from meeting planning to presentations, the IDEO workshop and session leadership to post-conference evaluation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided scholarships for 16 medical and biomedical engineering students to participate in the IEEE Healthcare Innovations and Point of Care Technologies Conference held in Seattle, WA October 8 - 10, 2014. The scholarships helped defray registration and travel expenses to allow the students to participate in the conference and in the special IDEO Design Innovation workshop, where they developed healthcare innovation ideas and learned design and prototype development as well as the process of translational engineering from professionals. The scholarships were awarded to students who would not otherwise be able to attend the conference, and special recruiting efforts aimed to increase the participation of women and underrepresented minorities, as well as medical students (who are important to attract to biomedical engineering conferences in order to facilitate cross-disciplinary collaboration). The outcomes of the conference were broadly disseminated via the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society network and media coverage, and will form the basis of a publication of a special issue of the IEEE Journal of Translational Engineering in Health and Medicine.

The Conference aimed to identify and fill gaps at the junction of clinical need and engineering applications. In this vein, emphasis was placed on novel innovations that have a foreseeable global impact on human health and disease and on their usability for both clinicians and patients in rural and underserved areas. The format of the sessions was designed to provide medical and engineering students with plenty of useful information and opportunities to contribute to the discussion.

The aim of the conference was to connect students, engineers, and scientists to stakeholders—including physicians, entrepreneurs, payers, patients, and policy makers—in order to work on critical issues in global healthcare. Thus, the conference's format encouraged fruitful interaction and ideation at all levels of experience and educational attainment. In addition to keynote lectures and panel discussions with leading researchers, clinicians, and representatives from industry, students, the leaders of the next generation, had an active role in the conference that included opportunities to present their own work and to participate in a special IDEO Design Innovation workshop with engineers, entrepreneurs, and clinicians.

Our goal was to maximize both the quantity and the quality of student participation in this important conference. Thus, stipends were available only to students who did not have a paper accepted at the conference (and thus presumably would attend whether they received a scholarship or not), in order to maximize the number of students who were able to attend the meeting. In order to maximize the quality of student participation, the scholarships included a unique once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to learn lifelong design development skills through an IDEO Design Innovation Workshop.  

The workshop was for participants with healthcare technology innovation ideas that they would like to develop, or who would like to learn about the process of innovation, design and product development.  Participants worked in teams through a structured design process to develop innovative ideas into potential products for healthcare applications.

During the workshop, 8 project teams of students and other participants brainstormed their ideas before the conference and then continued to work throughout the conference to advance their innovation toward meeting an unmet clinical need/challenge under the mentoring of experienced professionals and entrepreneurs from IDEO, a renowned design and innovation consulting company.  Students applied for the workshop either as Idea Generators or Idea Developers.
